fields.title: Corpse Bride
fields.review: A stop-motion movie made by Tim Burton, known for his grim themes. A man who's anxious about his upcoming arranged marriage accidentally proposes to a corpse while reciting his vows. The story is straightforward and ends happily, contrasting the dark setting of the entire movie. A great combination for me.

fields.title: Jurassic World Dominion
fields.review: Another movie from the Jurassic Park franchise, where recurring characters bump into each other to unravel the schemes of a suspicious genetics research center. I have to side with the online reviews for this one: it's nowhere near as impressive as the few first movies.

fields.title: Violet Evergarden: The Movie
fields.review: A continuation of the anime series with the same name. It tells a story of how an ex-soldier, now a scribe named Violet reunites with the major she loves after years of his speculated death. It's slow-paced and somewhat less intensive than the series, but the heartwarming end that wraps her tragic past is worth the time.

A post-apocalyptic Tim Burton movie, my favorite ever since I was a child. It's about nine small stitchpunk dolls named in numbers surviving against AI-equipped war machines in a world rid of living things. Watching it again after I grew up made me notice some plot inconsistencies, but the dark setting always awes me.

fields.title: A Whisker Away
fields.review: A cute story about a girl who turns into a cat just to see her crush. But it gets deeper as this ability soon becomes a form of escapism from her problems in life. She's such a relatable character for audiences of similar age dealing with internal conflict. The fantasy setting near the end isn't to my liking, but it's a charming movie overall.
